conclusion: To determine the static friction force on block D, analyze forces on each block and use Newton's second law.
Four blocks A, B, C, D are on a surface; B and C are connected by a spring; force F is applied to B.
Block A has forces: applied force F, normal force N_A, static friction f_AB from B.
Block B has forces: applied force F, normal force N_B, static friction f_BA from A, tension T, static friction f_BC from C.
Block C has forces: tension T, normal force N_C, static friction f_CB from B.
Block D has forces: normal force N_D, static friction f_DC from C.
All blocks move with the same acceleration a; consider the system as one block.
Total mass of the system is 4m (each block has mass m).
Net force on the system is F; using Newton's second law: F = 4ma.
For block D, static friction f_DC equals the force required to accelerate block D with acceleration a.
Force required to accelerate block D is f_DC = ma.
Force F is distributed equally among four blocks; force on each block is F/4.
Force on block D is f_DC = F/4.
The magnitude of the static friction force acting on block D is F/4.
